column3: Is the website intended to be copyrighted? Otherwise "Â© 2016 Bitcoin Core." should be removed no?\n

@Aquentus Copyright is inalienable and exists by default, every line of code, image, or text written has a copyright assignment by default (to the author unless under employment with no specific agreement otherwise). What is important is the license. In any case, it's not a subject for this ticket or this repository.\n
ACK\n
ACK\n

Concept ACK

(as in, whatever the new Core site's URL is, we should be pointing to it rather than bitcoin.org)
ACK\n

Why is this necessary? We already have https://bitcoin.org/en/bitcoin-core/

The new website seems "hardcoded". Why not fork from https://github.com/bitcoin-dot-org/bitcoin.org ?

Who is responsible for the domain and content. Is the process transparent?

Edit: It looks like the source code is available here: https://github.com/bitcoin-core/website.

@MarcoFalke We need our own voice because bitcoin.org's policies are their own. People conflate bitcoin.org with Bitcoin Core. You can read about the relationship and how it evolved [here](https://bitcoin.org/en/bitcoin-core/about-site) but this text is not enough, there needs to be physical separation.\n\nThe domain is owned by Wladamir, the contributing process is similar to Bitcoin Core see the
Concept ACK, but please link from the website to the GitHub source code repo. Otherwise it is really misleading and hard to verify where the content came from.\n

> please link from the website to the GitHub source code repo. 

It is linked in the contribution document.

> Otherwise it is really misleading and hard to verify where the content came from. 

linked from my comment, maybe we crossed streams :)
Would you also need to update the website in "contrib/debian"?\n
ACK\n
@MarcoFalke done\n
ACK\n
... why?\n
FYI: bitcoincore.org transfer is still in progress, all the necessary steps have been followed, the estimate from gandi.net is that it will be finished next monday\n

Concept ACK.

I think the domain looks fishy though. If bitcoincore.org is going to be used for the new site, it would be better.
@laanwj Lets wait if it's just a few more days; no need to cause a lot of confusion.\n

@btcdrak It is my understanding that bitcoin.org was very purposefully setup to NOT be run by the people who are making most of the changes to the bitcoin reference implementation. The people writing the software are not the people hosting the binaries. This was very much a conscious decision for the purpose of ensuring checks and balances in a decentralized development process.\n\nHaving a portio
@maaku to clarify there is no intention to move the binaries from bitcoin.org, however, the project needs it's own project website.\n

Right: there are no plans to move binary hosting. 
But making the README.md refer to the project website makes sense, though there's no hurry.
We should link the general bitcoin.org site as well as part of talking about the network/currency in general.
Updated for new URL, bitcoincore.org\n
I still think this needs a reference to bitcoin.org, for example in the "What is bitcoin" section.\n

I think it would be better to explain a little about why there are 2 websites in the readme file, just plonking bitcoincore.org at the top and having a different site just a few lines down is a bit odd.\n

It already says "For more information, as well as [binaries]" ...

Though, you are welcome to improve it.
@conor123 bitcoin.org is about bitcoin in general, bitcoincore.org is specifically about this project\n
